transcripts.text: Even though we kind of felt like this is coming, it's shocking to me just how restrictive and inhumane it is.

Governor Kay Ivey signed the strictest abortion bill in the country, making the procedure illegal at every stage of pregnancy, even in cases of incest or rape, unless the mother's life is in danger.  We're at the University of Alabama, where more than half the students here are from out of state.  Yahoo News is on the ground to find out just what they think of the new abortion ban.
This bill is very extreme and it kind of affects my viewpoint of living in the state itself.  I'm not planning on living here after I graduate.

I know a lot of people personally who are from out of state and who are very upset and who are talking, like even talking about transferring.  A lot of people who would have come here might not now.  I personally am against abortion, but I have, like I said, I've never been pregnant and neither have any of those men, so...
I wouldn't personally have an abortion myself.  However, I'm not here to judge other people.  I'm just here to support people and what they do.
I think it's absolutely ridiculous.  I think that even in the case of rape and incest, you should be able to get that abortion.

The bill passed by a vote of 25 to 6 and will make abortion and attempted abortion felony offenses.  While there's clear support for the bill, 58% of Americans say that abortion should be legal in all or most cases.  Many politicians, public figures, and citizens have strongly condemned the bill, warning of the repercussions it could have on women's rights as a whole.
If you're putting the doctor in jail, where's the man also doing that jail time?

But from a medical perspective, I feel like if they're going to be illegal and you're going to make it illegal, this is just going to cause unsafe abortions because you're not going to stop it.  You're just going to create illegal ones.

A lot of people are criticizing the people who voted for the bill because they were 25 white men.  And critics are saying, you know, you don't have a uterus.  Why are you making legislation about this?  What do you guys think about that?
Whether they have a uterus or not, you know, you can back up anything you want.  I feel like people shouldn't be judged for their decisions.
I think it's a lot easier for the men to vote for this abortion ban.
As a man, they don't really understand what a woman goes through.  It's 25 white men.  I don't think it's very, very reliable.

It seems like the past few years we've been in the spotlight over and over again for things that are not good, like first with Jeff Sessions, then with Roy Moore, and now with this.  And it's really frustrating for me because there's so much good stuff that's happening in Alabama.
The legislation here in the Senate, they need major work to even think about considering living here.
I think that we need a much better child care and foster care system because there's over 6,000 children who are waiting to be adopted in Alabama.
The one good thing that I've seen come out of this bill is let's uplift the abortion fund.  Let's talk about what resources are available.  Let's do what we can to help Alabama.

Seven states have already passed bills to narrow the window of abortion, and many believe the case could go all the way up to the Supreme Court, which could have major ramifications on the 1973 decision Roe v. Wade.  Keep following Yahoo News for the latest updates.  From the University of Alabama, I'm Kayla Jardine.
